title: ag.algebraic geometry - When every localization of the polynomial ring over a ring has finitely many idempotents
body: Let $R$ be a commutative ring such that every localization ring $R_r$ has finitely many idempotents for each non nilpotent element $r\in R$ . Why dose every localization ring $R[x]_{f(x)}$ have finitely many idempotents for each non nilpotent polynomial $f(x)\in R[x]$ ? ag.algebraic-geometry ac.commutative-algebra ra.rings-and-algebras sheaf-theory Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jul 4, 2020 at 17:50 asked Jul 4, 2020 at 16:12 Bazara 11 2 2 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 2 2 $\begingroup$ By quotient ring $R_r$, do you mean $R/(r)$ or the localization? $\endgroup$ Asvin –  Asvin 2020-07-04 17:32:02 +00:00 Commented Jul 4, 2020 at 17:32 $\begingroup$ @Asvin: thank you for your comment.
